I don't know much about signal processing, but would it be possible to
have=
 a dynamic sampling rate, where an output of the network controls
the speed=
, and this could be evolved along with the rest of the
behavior?

On 11/6/0=
5, Colin Green <cgreen@...> wrote:
> My initial function approxim=
ation experiment tried to approximate y=3Df(x)
> by feeding values of x and=
 comparing an ANN's output with the expected
> output. So the ANN is mappin=
g x directly to y.
>
> I decided to experiment with an alternative techniqu=
e whereby there is
> no input and I use the ANN as a sort of wave generator=
. I activate the
> network and take a reading and repeat this as many times=
 as I want. I
> can then match the outputs against an expected output and h=
opefully
> evolve ANNs that can generate a continuous wave form.
>
> This d=
oes seem to work to some extent, e.g. I can evolve sine wave
> generators e=
asily enough, and a square wave approximation has a lot of
> rough edges an=
d noise but the overall shape is there. So I decided to
> try something a b=
it more challenging, specifically the Mackey-Glass
> series, which can be m=
ade to generate a chaotic waveform. Here's were I
> noticed the first probl=
em.
>
> If I use a low sampling rate then the output from the series rises =
and
> falls within just a few activations of my ANN's and they can do a
> r=
easonably good job of tracking the function over short periods (I
> haven't=
 tried anything too long yet). If however I increase the sampling
> rate th=
en there may be many activations between rises and falls, but the
> kind of=
 small networks that I start out with when I initiase a run have
> a very f=
ast oscilaltion rate (or high natural frequency) due to their
> small size =
and compact interconnections. I suppose I could try and start
> with a popu=
lation of pre-built networks with a lower oscillation rate,
> but I don't t=
hink this is a solution for the general case where a
> function may have ma=
ny different harmonics.
>
> Anyway to give you an idea of the kind of resul=
ts I've been getting
> here's a link to a graph showing a short section of =
a mackey-glass
> waveform in black and an approximation in red. The trainin=
g data is
> shown on the first third of the graph up until the black line d=
rops to
> zero, the remaining two thirds show the network's response beyond=
 the
> training data.
>
> http://tinypic.com/fdhssg.png
>
> The graph shows=
 the network generating a fairly regular output that
> roughly matches the =
black line, but there is no or very little matching
> of the subtle variati=
ons. The low-res approximations I tried were
> generally better matching wa=
veforms.
>
> Colin.
